content.webTitle: Yale men's basketball team apologizes for public support of expelled captain

fields.headline: Yale men's basketball team apologizes for public support of expelled captain
fields.bodyText: Following a week and a half of campus unrest, the Yale men’s basketball team has apologized for its public support for former captain Jack Montague, whose family says he was “expelled” from the college. “Yale Men’s Basketball fully supports a healthy, safe and respectful campus climate where all students can flourish,” reads the statement, the first comments the team has made publicly about the controversy. “Our recent actions to show our support for one of our former teammates were not intended to suggest otherwise, but we understand that to many students they did. We apologize for the hurt we have caused and we look forward to learning and growing from these recent incidents,” it reads. Montague abruptly left the university last month, for reasons that are still unclear. His father said he was “expelled”, but it is unknown why. The university refused to comment on Montague’s withdrawal due to federal privacy laws around education. Yale police and New Haven police have no record of arrest or court hearing involving Montague. In the weeks since his departure, his teammates actively supported their ex-captain on numerous occasions, during their most successful basketball season in decades. Two weeks ago, during warm-up in a nationally televised game against Harvard, the team wore T-shirts emblazoned with “Gucci” (Montague’s nickname) and a “4” (his team number). The Yale Women’s Center released a statement in frustration at the team’s shirt protest, declaring: “We believe that their actions, and some community members’ responses, reflect toxic attitudes that persist on our campus.” For days after the T-shirt incident, posters appeared around campus criticising the team’s support and declaring “I stand with Yale women” and “Stop silencing women.” On Saturday, the dean of Yale College, Jonathan Holloway, emailed all undergraduate students about the on-campus war. “I want you to know that I have been following the public reactions to this week’s events involving the men’s basketball team’s symbolic T-shirts and the posters that appeared on campus in response to them,” he wrote. “I know that many of you are upset and angry, and that you are sharing deeply conflicting views. As you engage with each other, I ask that you also treat each other civilly.” After Saturday night’s game against Columbia, a win that sealed the Ivy League championship and guaranteed the team a berth in the NCAA tournament for the first time since 1962, teammate Justin Sears spoke to reporters about how the team spoke on FaceTime with Montague during a pre-game dinner. “He’s our leader,” said Sears. “He’s our captain. He’s still our captain. He knows how to bring people together, he knows how to motivate people and a big reason I’m here is because of him. He’s my brother, he’s all of our brothers and we miss him.” Teammate Khaliq Ghani played Saturday night’s big game with “Gucci” written on his wrist tape. Moments after the final siren, teammates held up four fingers in a salute to Montague’s shirt number, according to reports. In today’s apology statement, the team acknowledged its role as public ambassadors. “As student representatives of Yale we hope to use our positions on and off the court in a way that can make everyone proud,” it read.
